message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Constrained Markov Decision Processes
Paper Abstract: This report presents a unified approach for the study of constrained Markov decision processes with a countable state space and unbounded costs. We consider a single controller having several objectives; it is desirable to design a controller that minimize one of cost objective, subject to inequality constraints on other cost objectives. The objectives that we study are both the expected average cost, as well as the expected total cost (of which the discounted cost is a special case). We provide two frameworks: the case were costs are bounded below, as well as the contracting framework. We characterize the set of achievable expected occupation measures as well as performance vectors. This allows us to reduce the original control dynamic problem into an infinite Linear Programming. We present a Lagrangian approach that enables us to obtain sensitivity analysis. In particular, we obtain asymptotical results for the constrained control problem: convergence of both the value and the pol...
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Markov Decision Process"

Links: [{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Partially observable Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partially_observable_Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Decentralized partially observable Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_partially_observable_Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Talk:Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_model"},{"title":"Category:Markov processes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Markov_processes"},{"title":"Online optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_optimization"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Markov Decision Processes:

## Definition

A Markov decision process (MDP), also called a stochastic dynamic program or stochastic control problem, is a model for sequential decision making when outcomes are uncertain.(no content)A Markov decision process is a Markov chain in which state transitions depend on the current state and an action vector that is applied to the system.

## Key Characteristics

The name comes from its connection to Markov chains, a concept developed by the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov. The "Markov" in "Markov decision process" refers to the underlying structure of state transitions that still follow the Markov property. The process is called a "decision process" because it involves making decisions that influence these state transitions, extending the concept of a Markov chain into the realm of decision-making under uncertainty.

## Purpose and Application

Typically, a Markov decision process is used to compute a policy of actions that will maximize some utility with respect to expected rewards.(no content)Originating from operations research in the 1950s, MDPs have since gained recognition in a variety of fields, with applications ranging from robotics to queueing systems and population processes.

## Time Variations

In discrete-time Markov Decision Processes, decisions are made at discrete time intervals. In contrast, for continuous-time Markov decision processes, decisions can be made at any time the decision maker chooses. Continuous-time Markov decision processes can better model the decision-making process for a system that has continuous dynamics, i.e., the system dynamics are defined by ordinary differential equations (ODEs).

Links: [{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Fundamental theorem of linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_linear_programming"},{"title":"Basic solution (linear programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_solution_(linear_programming)"},{"title":"Multi-objective linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_linear_programming"},{"title":"GNU Linear Programming Kit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_Linear_Programming_Kit"},{"title":"Successive linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Successive_linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear genetic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_genetic_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming decoding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_decoding"},{"title":"Sequential linear-quadratic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_linear-quadratic_programming"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Linear Programming:

## Definition and Basics

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.(no content)More formally, linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

## Key Mathematical Concepts

Its feasible region is a convex polytope, which is a set defined as the intersection of finitely many half spaces, each of which is defined by a linear inequality. Its objective function is a real-valued affine (linear) function defined on this polytope. A linear programming algorithm finds a point in the polytope where this function has the largest (or smallest) value if such a point exists.(no content)The fundamental theorem of linear programming states, in a weak formulation, that the maxima and minima of a linear function over a convex polygonal region occur at the region's corners.

## Applications and Industries

Industries that use linear programming models include transportation, energy, telecommunications, and manufacturing. It has proven useful in modeling diverse types of problems in planning, routing, scheduling, assignment, and design.

## Historical Development

The problem of solving a system of linear inequalities dates back at least as far as Fourier, who in 1827 published a method for solving them. In the late 1930s, Soviet mathematician Leonid Kantorovich and American economist Wassily Leontief independently delved into the practical applications of linear programming.(no content)In 1947, Dantzig also invented the simplex method that, for the first time efficiently, tackled the linear programming problem in most cases.

Links: [{"title":"Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value"},{"title":"Expectation value (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expectation_value_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Conditional expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_expectation"},{"title":"Law of total expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_total_expectation"},{"title":"Talk:Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Expected_value"},{"title":"Variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance"},{"title":"Law of total variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_total_variance"},{"title":"Notation in probability and statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notation_in_probability_and_statistics"},{"title":"Martingale (probability theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martingale_(probability_theory)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010 January 6 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010_January_6"}]

I've completed the web search for "Expected value mathematics". Here are the key findings:

## What is Expected Value?

In probability theory, the expected value (also called expectation, expectancy, expectation operator, mathematical expectation, mean, expectation value, or first moment) is a generalization of the weighted average.(no content)The principle is that the value of a future gain should be directly proportional to the chance of getting it.

## Historical Background

In 1814, Pierre-Simon Laplace published his tract "Théorie analytique des probabilités", where the concept of expected value was defined explicitly as the product of the sum hoped for by the probability of obtaining it.(no content)The use of the letter E to denote "expected value" goes back to W. A. Whitworth in 1901.

## Different Contexts

The simplest and original definition deals with the case of finitely many possible outcomes, such as in the flip of a coin. With the theory of infinite series, this can be extended to the case of countably many possible outcomes. It is also very common to consider the distinct case of random variables dictated by (piecewise-)continuous probability density functions, as these arise in many natural contexts.

## Applications

Martingales are used to model fair games, where future expected winnings are equal to the current amount regardless of past outcomes. Additionally, equity is the sum of the values of the possible outcomes from a given position with each value multiplied by its probability of occurrence.

Web search results for query: "Discount factor economics"

Links: [{"title":"Discounting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounting"},{"title":"Stochastic discount factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_discount_factor"},{"title":"Discounted utility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_utility"},{"title":"Social discount rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_discount_rate"},{"title":"Exponential discounting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_discounting"},{"title":"Time preference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_preference"},{"title":"Discount rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discount_rate"},{"title":"Hyperbolic discounting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_discounting"},{"title":"Discounted cash flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_cash_flow"},{"title":"Discount function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discount_function"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the discount factor in economics:

## Definition

The discount factor is the factor by which a future cash flow must be multiplied in order to obtain the present value.

## Key Concepts

**Time Value of Money**: A dollar received now might grant the recipient the option to either use the dollar now or to invest it (gaining interest) and use it next year, whereas a dollar received next year can only be used next year.

**In Discounted Utility Models**: The utility of an event occurring at future time under a utility function, discounted back to the present using discount factor β shows that more distant events are less liked, with 0 < β < 1.

## Types of Discounting

The search results identify several approaches:

1. **Exponential Discounting**: Exponential discounting is a specific form of the discount function used in the analysis of choice over time, where the exponential discount factor is denoted as δ.

2. **Hyperbolic Discounting**: Hyperbolic discounting is a time-inconsistent model of delay discounting and is one of the cornerstones of behavioral economics.

3. **Stochastic Discount Factor**: The stochastic discount factor is used in financial economics and mathematical finance, with this definition being of fundamental importance in asset pricing.

## Applications

In economics, a discount function is used in economic models to describe the weights placed on rewards received at different points in time.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Lagrange multiplier method"

Links: [{"title":"Lagrange multiplier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multiplier"},{"title":"Lagrange multipliers on Banach spaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multipliers_on_Banach_spaces"},{"title":"Augmented Lagrangian method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmented_Lagrangian_method"},{"title":"Lagrangian relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_relaxation"},{"title":"Talk:Lagrange multiplier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lagrange_multiplier"},{"title":"Talk:Lagrange multiplier/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lagrange_multiplier/Archive_1"},{"title":"Lagrangian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_mechanics"},{"title":"Lagrange polynomial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_polynomial"},{"title":"Numerical methods for partial differential equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_partial_differential_equations"},{"title":"Active-set method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active-set_method"}]

## Lagrange Multiplier Method

In mathematical optimization, the method of Lagrange multipliers is a strategy for finding the local maxima and minima of a function subject to equation constraints (i.e., subject to the condition that one or more equations have to be satisfied exactly by the chosen values of the variables).

### How It Works

The method of Lagrange multipliers relies on the intuition that at a maximum, f(x, y) cannot be increasing in the direction of any neighboring point that also has g = 0. If it were, we could walk along g = 0 to get higher, meaning that the starting point wasn't actually the maximum. Viewed in this way, it is an exact analogue to testing if the derivative of an unconstrained function is 0.

### Extensions and Applications

The method of Lagrange multipliers can be extended to solve problems with multiple constraints using a similar argument.

The method has diverse applications across multiple fields:

- In Lagrangian Mechanics, the Euler-Lagrange equations can be augmented with Lagrange multipliers as a method to impose physical constraints on systems. When Lagrange multipliers are used, the constraint equations need to be simultaneously solved with the Euler-Lagrange equations.

- In many models in mathematical economics such as general equilibrium models, consumer behavior is implemented as utility maximization and firm behavior as profit maximization, both entities being subject to constraints such as budget constraints and production constraints. The usual way to determine an optimal solution is achieved by maximizing some function, where the constraints are enforced using Lagrangian multipliers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- In many models in mathematical economics such as general equilibrium models, consumer behavior is implemented as utility maximization and firm behavior as profit maximization, both entities being subject to constraints such as budget constraints and production constraints. The usual way to determine an optimal solution is achieved by maximizing some function, where the constraints are enforced using Lagrangian multipliers.
